news_summary: Recent discoveries and initiatives reveal groundbreaking deep-sea ecosystems, strengthen forest carbon sinks, advance nature-based climate solutions, and create vital wildlife corridors in key global regions.
news_summary_fr: Des découvertes et des initiatives récentes révèlent des écosystèmes sous-marins révolutionnaires, renforcent les puits de carbone forestiers, font progresser les solutions climatiques fondées sur la nature et créent des corridors vitaux pour la faune et la flore dans des régions clés du monde.
news_summary_es: Recientes descubrimientos e iniciativas revelan ecosistemas de aguas profundas pioneros, refuerzan los sumideros de carbono de los bosques, impulsan soluciones climáticas basadas en la naturaleza y crean corredores vitales para la fauna salvaje en regiones mundiales clave.

articles.title: Earth's deepest ecosystem discovered six miles below the sea
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02436-7Submersible dives reveal a startling diversity of life in the depths of the Pacific Ocean — plus, how respiratory infections could awaken dormant cancer cells.
articles.content:
Submersible dives reveal a startling diversity of life in the depths of the Pacific Ocean — plus, how respiratory infections could awaken dormant cancer cells.

Download the Nature Podcast 30 July 2025

In this episode:

00:45 The deepest ecosystem ever discovered

Researchers have dived down to more than 9,000 metres below the surface of the Pacific and discovered surprisingly complex communities of life living in deep ocean trenches. The new research shows an array of animal life that appears to be using methane as a source of energy. The researchers are planning more dives to learn more about this mysterious ecosystem and how these animals can thrive despite the extreme pressure they face.

Research Article: Peng et al

09:36 Research Highlights

A fossilized leg bone reveals an 11-million-year-old fight between a terror bird and a caiman, plus the anti-ageing secret of ‘immortal’ stars.

Research Highlight: Rumble in the Miocene: terror bird versus caiman

Research Highlight: ‘Immortal’ stars have an elixir of youth: dark matter

11:45 How infections could awaken dormant cancer

New research reveals that infection by a respiratory virus has the potential to awaken dormant cancer cells. In mice studies, a team showed that inflammation caused by infection with influenza or SARS-CoV-2 could initiate the awakening of breast cancer cells that had metastasized to the lungs. Observational studies using human health data also showed that a COVID-19 infection was associated with increased risk of lung metastasis and cancer death. While the precise mechanisms are unknown, the team say that understanding the process could help mitigate any risks of cancer progression caused by a viral infection.

Research Article: Chia et al.

News and Views: Inflammation during viral infection can rouse dormant cancer cells

21:45 Will physicists ever agree on quantum mechanics?

A survey of more than 1,100 physicists has revealed that there are widely different interpretations of what quantum mechanics means for our understanding or reality. Reporter Lizzie Gibney takes us through the different ideas physicists have and asks if such disagreements even matter.

Nature: Physicists disagree wildly on what quantum mechanics says about reality, Nature survey shows

Subscribe to Nature Briefing, an unmissable daily round-up of science news, opinion and analysis free in your inbox every weekday.

Never miss an episode. Subscribe to the Nature Podcast on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, YouTube Music or your favourite podcast app. An RSS feed for the Nature Podcast is available too.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of Earth's deepest ecosystem reveals remarkable biodiversity in an unexplored part of the ocean, highlighting the richness of life on our planet and potentially informing conservation efforts. Additionally, the scientific insight into how respiratory infections could awaken dormant cancer cells suggests important medical research implications.
articles.personality_title: Scientists discover vibrant life six miles deep in the ocean
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The deepest parts of the ocean have long been a mystery, with extreme pressure and darkness making exploration difficult. Scientists have been eager to learn more about these hidden underwater worlds.

**What happened**
Researchers used submersibles to dive over six miles (9,000 meters) below the Pacific Ocean’s surface. They found a surprisingly rich and complex ecosystem filled with diverse animals living in deep ocean trenches, the deepest ecosystem ever recorded.

**Impact**
This discovery reveals that life thrives even in the most extreme and previously unexplored ocean depths. Understanding this biodiversity helps us appreciate how rich our planet’s life really is and can guide future efforts to protect these fragile habitats.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to study these deep-sea communities further to learn how they survive and interact. This knowledge could improve conservation strategies and inspire new scientific research in biology and ecology.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Life’s amazing diversity reaches even the darkest, deepest ocean depths, reminding us how much there is still to discover on Earth.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques découvrent une vie vibrante à six miles de profondeur dans l'océan
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les parties les plus profondes de l'océan restent un mystère, car la pression extrême et l'obscurité rendent l'exploration difficile. Les scientifiques souhaitent en savoir plus sur ces mondes sous-marins cachés.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs ont utilisé des submersibles pour plonger à plus de six miles (9 000 mètres) sous la surface de l'océan Pacifique. Ils ont découvert un écosystème étonnamment riche et complexe, avec une grande diversité d'animaux vivant dans les fosses océaniques, l'écosystème le plus profond jamais enregistré.

**Impact**
Cette découverte montre que la vie prospère même dans les profondeurs extrêmes et peu explorées de l'océan. Comprendre cette biodiversité nous aide à apprécier la richesse de la vie sur notre planète et peut orienter la protection future de ces habitats fragiles.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient d'étudier davantage ces communautés des grands fonds pour comprendre comment elles survivent et interagissent. Ces connaissances pourraient améliorer les stratégies de conservation et inspirer de nouvelles recherches en biologie et écologie.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
La diversité incroyable de la vie atteint même les profondeurs les plus sombres et les plus profondes de l'océan, nous rappelant combien il reste à découvrir sur Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos descubren vida vibrante a seis millas de profundidad en el océano
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Las partes más profundas del océano han sido un misterio debido a la presión extrema y la oscuridad que dificultan la exploración. Los científicos han querido conocer más sobre estos mundos submarinos escondidos.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores usaron sumergibles para descender más de seis millas (9,000 metros) bajo la superficie del Océano Pacífico. Encontraron un ecosistema sorprendentemente rico y complejo, con diversos animales viviendo en trincheras oceánicas profundas, el ecosistema más profundo registrado.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento muestra que la vida prospera incluso en las partes más extremas y poco exploradas del océano. Entender esta biodiversidad nos ayuda a apreciar la riqueza de la vida en nuestro planeta y puede guiar futuros esfuerzos para proteger estos hábitats frágiles.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean estudiar estas comunidades marinas profundas para aprender cómo sobreviven e interactúan. Este conocimiento podría mejorar las estrategias de conservación e inspirar nuevas investigaciones científicas en biología y ecología.

**Frase para recordar**
La impresionante diversidad de la vida llega hasta las profundidades más oscuras y profundas del océano, recordándonos cuánto queda por descubrir en la Tierra.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a deep ocean trench illuminated by soft bioluminescent glows, showing diverse, stylized marine creatures like tube worms, shrimp, and fish thriving around methane vents under immense pressure, with an abstract representation of awakening energy waves gently stirring dormant forms in shadowy lung-like coral structures nearby.

articles.reasoning: The article discusses actionable research aimed at improving the monitoring and management of forest carbon sinks, which supports the European Union's climate goals and the Green Deal. This represents significant environmental progress and contributes positively to climate change mitigation efforts.
articles.personality_title: Europe takes a big step to protect forests and fight climate change
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Forests play a huge role in fighting climate change because they absorb carbon dioxide, a major greenhouse gas. The European Union wants to protect and boost this natural carbon storage as part of its Green Deal, a plan to make Europe climate-neutral by 2050. But to do this well, we need better ways to track and manage forest carbon.

**What happened**
Scientists and experts have outlined clear research steps to improve how we monitor and model Europe’s forest carbon sinks. This means using better tools and data to understand how much carbon forests are storing and how management choices affect this. These recommendations help guide smarter forest care and support EU climate goals.

**Impact**
By improving forest monitoring and management, Europe can protect these natural carbon sinks more effectively. This helps slow down climate change, supports biodiversity, and strengthens the success of the European Green Deal. It also means forest managers get clearer information to make the best decisions.

**What's next step**
The EU and forest organizations will work to apply these research ideas into real policies and technologies. This includes better satellite monitoring, new models to predict forest carbon changes, and training for forest managers. The goal is to keep forests healthy and their carbon storage strong.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Better science and smarter forest care are helping Europe protect its forests as a powerful tool against climate change.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Europe fait un grand pas pour protéger les forêts et lutter contre le changement climatique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les forêts jouent un rôle majeur dans la lutte contre le changement climatique car elles absorbent le dioxyde de carbone, un gaz à effet de serre important. L’Union européenne souhaite protéger et renforcer ce stockage naturel de carbone dans le cadre de son Pacte vert, un plan visant la neutralité climatique en 2050. Mais pour bien faire, il faut mieux suivre et gérer le carbone des forêts.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des scientifiques et experts ont présenté des étapes de recherche claires pour améliorer la surveillance et la modélisation des puits de carbone forestiers en Europe. Cela signifie utiliser de meilleurs outils et données pour comprendre combien de carbone les forêts stockent et comment les choix de gestion influencent cela. Ces recommandations aident à mieux gérer les forêts et à soutenir les objectifs climatiques de l’UE.

**Impact**
En améliorant la surveillance et la gestion des forêts, l’Europe peut mieux protéger ces puits naturels de carbone. Cela aide à ralentir le changement climatique, soutient la biodiversité et renforce le succès du Pacte vert européen. Cela donne aussi aux gestionnaires forestiers des informations plus claires pour prendre les meilleures décisions.

**Prochaine étape**
L’UE et les organisations forestières vont travailler à mettre en œuvre ces idées de recherche dans des politiques et technologies concrètes. Cela inclut une meilleure surveillance par satellite, de nouveaux modèles pour prédire les changements de carbone forestier et la formation des gestionnaires. L’objectif est de garder les forêts en bonne santé et leur capacité de stockage de carbone forte.

**Message en une phrase**
Une meilleure science et une gestion plus intelligente des forêts aident l’Europe à protéger ses forêts comme un outil puissant contre le changement climatique.
articles.personality_title_es: Europa da un gran paso para proteger los bosques y combatir el cambio climático
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los bosques juegan un papel clave en la lucha contra el cambio climático porque absorben dióxido de carbono, un gas de efecto invernadero importante. La Unión Europea quiere proteger y aumentar este almacenamiento natural de carbono como parte de su Pacto Verde, un plan para hacer Europa climáticamente neutral para 2050. Pero para lograrlo bien, necesitamos mejores formas de monitorear y gestionar el carbono de los bosques.

**Qué pasó**
Científicos y expertos han propuesto pasos claros de investigación para mejorar cómo se monitorean y modelan los sumideros de carbono en los bosques europeos. Esto implica usar mejores herramientas y datos para entender cuánto carbono almacenan los bosques y cómo las decisiones de manejo lo afectan. Estas recomendaciones ayudan a cuidar los bosques de forma más inteligente y a apoyar las metas climáticas de la UE.

**Impacto**
Al mejorar el monitoreo y la gestión forestal, Europa puede proteger estos sumideros naturales de carbono de forma más eficaz. Esto ayuda a frenar el cambio climático, apoya la biodiversidad y fortalece el éxito del Pacto Verde Europeo. También proporciona a los gestores forestales información más clara para tomar las mejores decisiones.

**Próximo paso**
La UE y las organizaciones forestales trabajarán para aplicar estas ideas de investigación en políticas y tecnologías reales. Esto incluye mejor monitoreo satelital, nuevos modelos para predecir cambios en el carbono forestal y capacitación para los gestores. El objetivo es mantener los bosques saludables y su capacidad para almacenar carbono fuerte.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Una mejor ciencia y un cuidado más inteligente de los bosques están ayudando a Europa a proteger sus bosques como una herramienta poderosa contra el cambio climático.

articles.title: Towards more effective nature-based climate solutions in global forests
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 30 July 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09116-6A strategy to improve the implementation of nature-based climate solutions in global forests for climate mitigation is described, comprising four key components to highlight notable science and policy considerations and providing solutions to improve rigour.

articles.personality_title: A new strategy boosts forest-based climate solutions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Forests are vital in fighting climate change because they absorb carbon dioxide, a major greenhouse gas. Using nature itself to help reduce climate impacts is known as nature-based climate solutions.

**What happened**
Scientists have developed a clear strategy to make nature-based climate solutions in forests more effective. This plan highlights important science and policy ideas, aiming to improve how these solutions are applied worldwide.

**Impact**
By focusing on four key areas, the strategy helps ensure forest conservation and restoration efforts truly capture more carbon and protect ecosystems. This means better climate mitigation and healthier forests for the future.

**What's next step**
The next move is to put this strategy into action globally, encouraging policymakers and environmental groups to use these improved methods. Monitoring and adapting the approach will help maximize benefits.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A thoughtful new strategy is making forest-based climate solutions stronger and more reliable in the fight against climate change.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle stratégie renforce les solutions climatiques basées sur les forêts
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les forêts jouent un rôle essentiel dans la lutte contre le changement climatique car elles absorbent le dioxyde de carbone, un gaz à effet de serre important. Utiliser la nature elle-même pour réduire les impacts climatiques s'appelle les solutions climatiques basées sur la nature.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des scientifiques ont élaboré une stratégie claire pour rendre ces solutions plus efficaces dans les forêts. Ce plan met en avant des idées clés en science et en politique pour améliorer leur application dans le monde entier.

**Impact**
En se concentrant sur quatre domaines clés, la stratégie aide à garantir que la conservation et la restauration des forêts captent réellement plus de carbone et protègent les écosystèmes. Cela signifie une meilleure atténuation du climat et des forêts plus saines.

**Prochaine étape**
La prochaine étape est de mettre en œuvre cette stratégie à l’échelle mondiale, en encourageant les décideurs et les groupes environnementaux à adopter ces méthodes améliorées. Le suivi et l’adaptation permettront de maximiser les bénéfices.

**Message en une phrase**
Une nouvelle stratégie réfléchie rend les solutions climatiques basées sur les forêts plus fortes et plus fiables dans la lutte contre le changement climatique.
articles.personality_title_es: Una nueva estrategia fortalece las soluciones climáticas basadas en bosques

articles.title: Where Andes meet Amazon, a new ‘lifeline’ for wildlife
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise, wildlife around the world are on the move, a new protected corridor in one of the planet’s most biodiverse countries aims to help.
articles.content:
As global temperatures rise, wildlife around the world are on the move, and one of the planet’s most biodiverse countries is no exception.

In central Ecuador, where the Andes meet the Amazon, lies a patchwork of protected areas and Indigenous territories. But climate change and persistent deforestation are widening the gaps between them — leaving species like jaguars, tapirs and monkeys with few safe paths to find more suitable habitat.

The solution: Stitch some of these areas back together.

Today, the Ecuadorian government, with support from Conservation International, World Wildlife Fund and the Global Environment Facility, announced the Palora-Pastaza corridor, which links protected forests with Indigenous territories to enable wildlife to more easily migrate to higher and more temperate elevations.

Spanning 316,000 hectares (781,000 acres) — an area roughly the size of Rhode Island — the corridor is the largest of its kind in Ecuador’s Amazon.

“Rising temperatures coupled with deforestation are pushing wildlife into smaller and smaller areas,” said Joy Woolfson, who leads the Amazonian Connectivity Corridors project for Conservation International-Ecuador. “Corridors that connect remaining patches of healthy habitat are a lifeline."

© Esteban Barrera

A jaguar in the Palora-Pastaza conservation corridor.

But where will wildlife migrate in the future? To answer this, Conservation International and EcoCiencia-Kolibria analyzed factors including the distance between primary forest and ease of travel, considering roads and landscapes.

Protected areas are one of conservation’s most effective tools, but by design, they can create isolated islands of healthy habitat for wildlife, Woolfson said. Corridors help bridge these gaps, linking fragmented ecosystems and providing safe routes for wildlife in search of food, mates or space.

Though protected areas typically limit human activity, protected corridors are different: They're designed to support wildlife and people, allowing sustainable land use while allowing animals room to roam.

© Esteban Barrera

A South American tapir in the Palora-Pastaza conservation corridor.

With Sangay National Park in the Andes to the west and Indigenous territories in the Amazon to the east, establishing the protected corridor required buy-in from local and Indigenous communities whose ancestral lands it connects to, Woolfson said.

Eighty-four percent of the land in the Palora-Pastaza corridor belongs to three Indigenous communities — the Shuar, Achuar and Kichwa — who along with two provincial and six municipal governments elected to include their territories in the protected corridor. Since 2023, Conservation International has worked with representatives from each group to plan and manage the corridor and ensure its long-term protection.

“The forest is important to us. Our father always told us to share with other communities — show others the importance of protecting the forest,” said José Vargas, president of the Arutam Forest, a Shuar core area located within the corridor. “It makes me happy to see other nationalities participating, because unity will help us conserve nature.”

Without support from these communities, establishing the corridor would have been impossible, Woolfson said. As research has repeatedly shown, Indigenous peoples are some of the most effective stewards of the environment, and deforestation on Indigenous-managed lands is consistently lower than average.

The corridor, its backers say, will directly benefit more than 2,000 people who live in the area by providing them with funding or technical assistance to shift to sustainable farming practices and livelihoods.

Woolfson says that the effort is part of a larger strategy in Ecuador, where there is little remaining land in the country — about the size of the U.S. state of Nevada — to designate as protected.

“Ecuador is a small country,” she said. “Even in the protected areas that we have now, a good portion is occupied by people. By targeting protected corridors, we’re maximizing protected areas’ potential, while also protecting wildlife and the livelihoods of people living there."

©Esteban Barrera

The vast majority of the new conservation corridor belongs to three Indigenous communities. Deforestation on Indigenous-managed lands is consistently lower than average.

Mary Kate McCoy is a staff writer at Conservation International. Want to read more stories like this? Sign up for email updates. Also, please consider supporting our critical work.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the creation of a new protected corridor to aid wildlife migration in response to climate change, representing a significant conservation success and environmental progress that benefits biodiversity.
articles.personality_title: New wildlife corridor connects Andes and Amazon to help animals adapt
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
In Ecuador, where the Andes mountains meet the Amazon rainforest, many animals like jaguars and monkeys live across protected lands and Indigenous territories. But climate change and deforestation are breaking these safe areas apart, making it hard for animals to move and find better homes.

**What happened**
A new protected corridor has been created to link these separated areas. This corridor acts like a safe passageway for wildlife to travel between habitats, helping them move in response to changing temperatures and environmental conditions.

**Impact**
This corridor gives animals more space and options to survive despite climate challenges. It helps preserve Ecuador’s rich biodiversity by allowing species to find suitable habitats and keep their populations healthy.

**What’s next step**
Efforts will focus on maintaining and expanding these corridors, while working with local communities to protect the land. This will ensure wildlife can continue to adapt to climate change over time.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Connecting protected areas with wildlife corridors is a smart and hopeful way to help animals thrive as our planet changes.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau corridor pour la faune relie les Andes et l’Amazonie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
En Équateur, où les Andes rencontrent la forêt amazonienne, de nombreux animaux comme les jaguars et les singes vivent dans des zones protégées et des territoires indigènes. Mais le changement climatique et la déforestation fragmentent ces espaces sûrs, rendant difficile la migration des animaux.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Un nouveau corridor protégé a été créé pour relier ces zones séparées. Ce corridor sert de passage sécurisé pour que la faune puisse se déplacer entre les habitats, leur permettant de s’adapter aux changements de température et d’environnement.

**Impact**
Ce corridor offre plus d’espace et d’options aux animaux pour survivre malgré le climat changeant. Il aide à préserver la biodiversité riche de l’Équateur en permettant aux espèces de trouver des habitats adaptés et de maintenir leurs populations.

**Prochaine étape**
Les efforts porteront sur le maintien et l’extension de ces corridors, en collaboration avec les communautés locales pour protéger les terres. Cela garantira que la faune puisse continuer à s’adapter au changement climatique.

**Une phrase clé**
Relier les zones protégées avec des corridors pour la faune est une solution intelligente et pleine d’espoir pour aider les animaux à prospérer face aux changements de la planète.
articles.personality_title_es: Un nuevo corredor para la fauna conecta los Andes y el Amazonas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En Ecuador, donde los Andes se encuentran con la selva amazónica, muchos animales como jaguares y monos viven en áreas protegidas y territorios indígenas. Pero el cambio climático y la deforestación están fragmentando estos espacios seguros, dificultando que los animales se muevan.

**Qué pasó**
Se creó un nuevo corredor protegido para unir estas áreas separadas. Este corredor funciona como un paso seguro para que la vida silvestre viaje entre hábitats, ayudándoles a adaptarse a los cambios de temperatura y ambientales.

**Impacto**
Este corredor brinda más espacio y opciones para que los animales sobrevivan a pesar de los desafíos climáticos. Ayuda a preservar la rica biodiversidad de Ecuador al permitir que las especies encuentren hábitats adecuados y mantengan sus poblaciones.

**Próximo paso**
Los esfuerzos se centrarán en mantener y ampliar estos corredores, trabajando con las comunidades locales para proteger las tierras. Esto asegurará que la vida silvestre pueda seguir adaptándose al cambio climático.

**Resumen en una frase**
Conectar áreas protegidas con corredores para la vida silvestre es una forma esperanzadora e inteligente de ayudar a los animales a prosperar mientras nuestro planeta cambia.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a lush Andean-Amazon landscape where a majestic jaguar, a South American tapir, and a playful monkey traverse a vibrant natural corridor linking towering misty mountains to dense tropical forests, with softly glowing silhouettes of Indigenous territory borders gently woven into the terrain, symbolizing harmony between wildlife migration and Indigenous stewardship.
